Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Story: I was sitting in the break room, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my younger brother vent about our latest argument. He was upset, and I knew I needed to be patient, to listen without judgment, to show him the respect he deserved even when we disagreed. That’s what being a good brother meant—being there, understanding our differences, not letting frustration get the better of me. But just as he started to open up, my pager buzzed. Room 214. I knew that room—Mrs. Carter, who had just received a devastating diagnosis. She needed me, too. As a nursing assistant, I was expected to provide comfort, to sit with her, to offer a shoulder to cry on. I could hear her sobs from the hallway. My brother’s voice wavered in my ear, “Are you even listening?” My heart twisted. Both needed me, both expected my full attention and compassion. I felt torn, guilt pressing in from both sides, unsure how to be the brother my sibling needed and the caregiver my patient deserved, all at the same time.
